title: 16 Natural Remedies for Anxiety Relief — Talkspace
author: Our Editorial Standards Reviewed
description: There are many people battling with anxiety who have learned to reduce it naturally. Discover therapist-approved natural remedies for anxiety.
cleaned_text: Published On: March 14, 2022 Reviewed On: March 14, 2022 Updated On: July 5, 2023 Updated on 04/24/2023 Anxiety ( [generalized anxiety disorder](https://www.talkspace.com/mental-health/conditions/generalized-anxiety-disorder/)) affects more than [18%](https://adaa.org/understanding-anxiety/facts-statistics) of the population in the United States each year. That's [more than 40 million Americans](https://adaa.org/understanding-anxiety/facts-statistics) who deal with a highly treatable mental health condition. However, many people go untreated, which can make your anxiety feel like it's totally derailing your life. It can make simple tasks feel impossible, and relationships and normal daily routines feel downright daunting. It can even trigger a panic attack, which can feel just as debilitating. There is good news, though. Beyond therapy and prescription medication, several natural remedies for anxiety relief have proven effective. As you explore these natural remedies to alleviate anxiety, be sure to consult with a licensed doctor or psychiatrist to find a holistic treatment that works for you. Read on to learn about all the holistic remedies for anxiety and discover which natural remedy or herbal remedy you can utilize to bring peace and calm back into your life. Therapy can come in all forms and styles and provide you with valuable tools to manage your anxiety. Individual therapy allows you to open up to a professional 1:1, learn more about your anxiety, and practice techniques that will help you cope. On the other hand, [group therapy](https://www.talkspace.com/blog/group-therapy-explained-benefits/) can be really [effective](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1077722909000169) in treating anxiety since you'll be with others who understand what you're experiencing. "Human beings were designed to be social and benefit from being in groups. Sharing anxiety-inducing events within a group provides comfort in the fact that you're not going through it alone. There is a natural healing component in connection and shared experience." Magnesium is a mineral that many Americans simply don't get enough of naturally, despite the abundance of [research](https://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/9/5/429/htm) out there showing it might be an effective natural treatment for anxiety. Magnesium is found in foods such as: Of course, you can always take a supplement to get your daily dose of magnesium*, but be sure to talk to your doctor before starting any new vitamins or supplements to ensure you're getting the right dose and that nothing will interfere with any other medications you're currently taking. Vitamin D is linked to levels of [serotonin](https://www.talkspace.com/blog/serotonin-what-is-defintion/), the mood-boosting hormone that aids in focus and helps you feel calm. Some [research](https://www.biomed.cas.cz/physiolres/pdf/64%20Suppl%202/64_S101.pdf) has found a link between anxiety disorders, depression, and vitamin D deficiency. It's important that you speak with a therapist and primary doctor about getting lab tests done on your vitamin D levels. This can help determine if a deficiency is contributing to your [anxiety symptoms](https://www.talkspace.com/mental-health/conditions/generalized-anxiety-disorder/symptoms/). From there, you can determine next steps with a doctor to increase your vitamin D levels. You can up your vitamin D levels by spending time outdoors in the sun, eating fatty fish, ensuring you get enough fortified foods, or taking a supplement. *You should talk to your doctor before adding any [vitamins for anxiety](https://www.talkspace.com/mental-health/conditions/articles/vitamins-for-anxiety/) to your diet. Omega-3 fatty acids are incredibly beneficial to brain health. Unfortunately, it's not something that your body can make. We get omega-3s through our diet. Some [studies](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphys.2018.01047/full) have shown that omega-3s found in fish oil can help to reduce anxiety. Vitamin B nutrients work together to offer several health benefits. B vitamins might prove beneficial in [how to deal with anxiety](https://www.talkspace.com/blog/how-to-deal-with-anxiety/) because they help your body process stress response. You can generally get ample B vitamins through your diet, but for some, like vegans or vegetarians, it can be tough to get enough solely through food. It can be worth seeking out a supplement*, though, since [research](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28656970/) has found that low levels of B12 might be linked to depression and anxiety. If you check the ingredients list of anti anxiety medication, you'll see some of them contain this amino acid. L-theanine can be found in black and green herbal tea and is an amino acid that some [research](https://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/8/1/53) shows might have an anti-anxiety effect. Don't confuse CBD with THC (which is the mood-altering substance in marijuana). Without the THC component, [CBD oil](https://www.talkspace.com/blog/is-cbd-oil-good-for-mental-health/) is a natural remedy that can be taken with little to no side effects that could prevent you from working, driving a car, or otherwise going about your day with the ability to function. CBD could be beneficial in helping calm the nerves. It can help to think of CBD somewhat similarly to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), but it's available without a prescription. While it's true that talk therapy (also known as psychotherapy) can be hugely effective in treating anxiety, there are other alternative [forms of therapy](https://www.talkspace.com/blog/different-types-therapy-psychotherapy-best/) that can work to reduce anxiety as well. Some of the popular [types of therapy for anxiety](https://www.talkspace.com/mental-health/conditions/generalized-anxiety-disorder/therapy-treatment-types/) that many people have found success with include: The Eastern, ancient practice known as acupuncture has been considered an [effective treatment](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25595195/) for anxiety for thousands of years. [Studies](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30221438/) show a link between spending time with pets and reduced anxiety. If your anxiety levels get to the point that it starts impacting your daily life, consider getting a service animal trained to assist people with generalized anxiety disorder or chronic anxiety. Some [ research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3683289/) shows that diffusing or wearing essential oils (like lavender essential oil or peppermint essential oil) known for their relaxing, calming properties is a natural treatment for anxiety. Hypnotherapy is thought to potentially [reduce](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00029157.2017.1288608?journalCode=ujhy20) fear, stress, anxiety, and panic disorder. In some [studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5072238/), music has been found to help calm the mind and reduce overall symptoms of anxiety. "Music may be one of the most common forms of treatment for anxiety. Music can change your mood by shifting attention to lyrics while experiencing a different frequency and vibration." Regularly practicing meditation can help you keep your emotions in check. [Mindfulness meditation](https://www.talkspace.com/blog/mindfulness-meditation-definition-guide-benefits/) has been found, according to some [research](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2010-05835-004), to be very impactful in helping people overcome stress and reduce anxiety. For a lot of people, writing can be a great release for pent-up stress and anxiety. [ Studies](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30221438/) have shown that teenagers and children who have anxiety symptoms can benefit from [journaling for their mental health](https://www.talkspace.com/blog/journaling-for-mental-health/). Making an effort to get outdoors and into nature can have an incredible impact on your mental health. [Research](https://www.apa.org/monitor/2020/04/nurtured-nature) continues to suggest, through mounting evidence, that spending time in nature is not only beneficial for physical health, but it's also a natural mood-booster, anxiety reducer, and offers significant cognitive benefits, too. "Spending time in nature can lower your stress levels and increase your sense of well-being. The sound of the waves can be therapeutic as well as trees and birds chirping. Finding your natural environment can bring inner peace." Caffeine is a known stimulant, and while it can be great for those sluggish mornings when you want to add some pep to your step, that jittery, on-edge feeling that comes after your cup of Joe might be contributing to your anxiety. [Studies](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/advances-in-psychiatric-treatment/article/neuropsychiatric-effects-of-caffeine/7C884B2106D772F02DA114C1B75D4EBF) have shown that the physical symptoms stemming from caffeine intake can include shakiness and a rapid heartbeat, both of which are symptoms of, and can induce anxiety and panic attacks. If you're looking for ideas on how to reduce anxiety naturally, cutting back on caffeine might help. Still want that nice warm start to your morning but looking for something other than coffee? Some types of teas, especially the herbal and decaffeinated varieties, are well known to be a natural treatment and herbal remedy for anxiety. Kava, chamomile, and lavender teas are both soothing herbal tea blends that may help to calm the nerves. Chamomile has the antioxidant apigenin, which might help [reduce symptoms of anxiety](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6472148/) by blinding certain receptors in your brain. Lavender has also been [ shown to help](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6007527/) with anxiety, restlessness, agitation, nervousness, and sleep issues. Exercising does more than just keep you in good physical shape. Numerous [studies](http://dx.doi.org/10.1136/bjsports-2012-091287) have proven that getting your heart-rate up can do wonders for your mental health, too. Can't get to the gym every single day? That's OK...even just a brisk walk, a short circuit routine, or a bike ride can help you clear your head, reduce stress, and ultimately, alleviate anxiety symptoms overall. It sounds so simple, but the truth is, laughter really can be the best medicine...for anxiety. The natural anxiety remedy is [known](https://journals.physiology.org/doi/full/10.1152/advan.00030.2017) to boost endorphins and reduce stress hormones like dopamine, cortisol, and epinephrine. Laughing can help you refocus and destress, all while allowing you to let go of the anxious feelings and thoughts that might be interfering in your life. Smoking has been linked to anxiety disorders and is known to change the pathways in the brain that are associated with symptoms related to anxiety. Some [research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3683289/) has even shown that the earlier you limit smoking — or quit altogether — the better the chance is you reduce your risk of developing an anxiety disorder later on in your life. There is no one size fits all method for anxiety relief and [how to treat anxiety.](https://www.talkspace.com/mental-health/conditions/generalized-anxiety-disorder/how-to-treat/) If you're seeking alternative, herbal remedies or natural remedies for anxiety that can help reduce your symptoms, know that there are options out there for you. Yes, it's true that sometimes you might need the help of a therapist, doctor, or even [ anti-anxiety medication](https://www.talkspace.com/mental-health/conditions/generalized-anxiety-disorder/medications/). That said, there are several things you can do to help complement your [ online therapy](https://www.talkspace.com/online-therapy/) or manage your anxiety on your own. At the end of the day, living a healthier, productive, rewarding life is everyone's goal. Knowing some of these holistic remedies for anxiety can only serve to help you get to that peaceful place you long to live in. *You should talk to your doctor before adding any supplement to your diet.
